creator: com12

content:
Depends upon what server you are talking about and what type of account is used in Thunderbird eg: POP or IMAP and what settings are you are using.

EG: If you have a POP account.

Pop accounts can only get access to the server Inbox to download emails, there is no synchronisation between any server folder and any pop account folder.

Menu icon > Account Settings

  • Select 'Server Settings' for pop mail account.
  • Select checkbox: 'Check for new messages at tartup
  • Select checkbox: 'Check for new messages every eg: 10 minutes'
  • Select checkbox: 'Automatically download new messages'

If you want to download full copies of emails and at the same time delete the copy on the server:

  • DO NOT Select checkbox: 'Fetch Headers only'
  • DO NOT Select checkbox: 'Leave messages on server'

If you want to download full copies of emails, but leave copy on the server:

  • DO NOT Select checkbox: 'Fetch Headers only'
  • Select checkbox: 'Leave messages on server'

If in addition you want to leave copy on server, but only for a short period and then remove copy off server:

  • Select checkbox: 'For at most eg: 14 days'

OR if you want to leave copy on server until you delete it.

  • Select checkbox: 'Until I delete them'


Please note some servers can have a few quirks eg: gmail or any server using a gmail style. Let's assume you download full copies and have selected to 'Leave message on server' and 'Until I delete them' When you use a POP account for a gmail email address you have no access to the gmail Trash. So any email you delete in the Pop account will only get the 'Inbox' label removed and the email will still be on the server in the 'All Mail' folder which is where gmail stores all your emails. This means periodically you would be forced to logon to the gmail webmail account via a browser, access the 'All Mail' folder and manually locate and delete the emails you have already deleted within Thunderbird.

IMAP is a different type of account. IMAP is designed to store all emails on the server, but offer full synchronised access to all of the server folders, so you can see an identical copy in Thunderbird imap account. In an imap account, any email you delete will get deleted off the server. This also means if you logon to your webmail account and delete emails, then when you open Thunderbird, all of those emails will be auto deleted from the imap account - why - because imap folders synchronise with server folders to display what is held on server. The benefit of this means you can access via webmail, or Thunderbird imap account or an imap account via a phone or other computer and still see all the same folders and emails. However, you should not think of the downloaded copy in Thunderbird as a separate independent copy because it can only display what is held on the server. You can download full copies or headers on a per folder basis and you can create a backup of your Thunderbird profile to another external device to ensure you have more than just the one copy on server.


In both POP and IMAP accounts: When you download full copy of email, it gets written to an mbox text file which has same name as folder eg: Inbox. The next downloaded emails gets appended to same file. So in the end it's like one text document where each email is like a paragraph. When you delete or move the email, a marker is set up to say 'mark as deleted and hide'. This means you do not see the deleted email unless it's moved to another folder, but the original copy is still in the original file. This helps if you need to quickly recover the email. However, over time you end up with a large text document containing loads of 'marked as deleted' emails which consumes space and starts to look messy. It also becomes more prone to get corrupted. You have to properly delete those emails - do some basic house cleaning called 'compacting' - this properly deletes the emails and this will also ensure they get deleted off the server. Additional Info on compacting:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/compacting-folders

Manually compact a folder:

  • Right click on folder and select 'Compact'

The Inbox, Drafts and Junk folders need frequent compacting as they get the most 'moving' or deleteing of emails.

I would suggest :

  1. Check your Account Settings to ensure all is set up to do as you require.
  2. Compact folders.
  3. Check the webmail account

If you have a Pop account and want to change to an imap account, then you cannot simply alter the server settings. In Thunderbird, you have to set up a 'New' > 'Existing mail account' for that email address and set up as an imap account using imap server settings as determined by the server requirements.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Please logon to gmail webmail account via a browser for that particular email address.

  • Click on the gear wheel icon and select 'See all Settings'
  • Select 'Labels'
  • First it lists 'System Labels' - this is the area to look in
  • Q: Do you see a 'Trash' folder or a 'Bin' folder ? In my case gmail calls it 'Bin'. In your case it may be 'Trash'.
  • See image below. Bin is under 'System Labels' and 'Show in imap' is selected.
  • This 'System Label' Trash/Bin is the one you have to use.

Q: what is it called in your webmail 'Trash' or 'Bin' or something else ?

then it lists 'Categories' and at the bottom 'Labels' - these labels are the ones you created. As an example mine has a 'Junk' folder - I do not really use it - I created it as an example. Q: Do you see a label called 'Trash' in that 'Labels' area ? If yes, then I suggest you delete it.

At this point I'm assuming you only have one 'Trash' folder and it is listed under 'System Labels' and it has 'Show in imap' selected.

Q: Are the emails you deleted displaying in the webmail 'Trash' folder ? Q: Are the emails you deleted displaying in the webmail 'All Mail' folder? If you see deleted emails in the 'All Mail' folder and you need to recover any of them, you can reapply a label eg: Inbox. see image as guide below.

Thunderbird Checks: check Subscribe is set up

  • Right click on gmail account name folder and select 'Subscribe'
  • Click on 'Refresh'
  • select the 'Trash' (or 'Bin') folder in list
  • click on 'Subscribe'
  • Click on 'OK'

Repair the Trash folder.

  • Right click on 'Trash' folder and select 'Properties'
  • Click on 'Repair folder' button
  • click on 'OK'

Check Account Settings:

  • Menu icon > Account Settings
  • Select 'Server Settings' for the problem account

'When I delete a message'

  • Select 'Move it to this folder' select 'Trash on correct gmail account email address'

If you do not want the 'Trash' to get auto emptied each time you exit Thunderbird: Under 'Message Storage' Do NOT select the 'Empty Deleted folder on exit' option.

Please note: Every 30 days - Gmail will auto delete emails you put into the gmail 'Trash' folder.

  • Select 'Synchronisation & Storage' for the problem account
  • Click on 'Advanced' button
  • Make sure the checkbox for 'Bin/ Trash' folder is selected
  • Click on OK.
  • Select 'Synchronise all messages locally regardless of age.'

Exit Thunderbird - wait a few momens for background processes to complete then restart Thunderbird. Wait for all checks to complete. Delete and email you do not want. select the 'Trash' folder
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thank you for going through every step! It appears that somehow I missed the Subscribe setup in Thunderbird, where for some reason the Trash folder was not selected. I checked the box and now everything is working perfect! Everything else you mentioned was setup correctly.

Thanks again!
creator: bogdan14

content: Thanks for the feedback on what you discovered. Good to hear you are all up and running again.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If you sent them then they should be in the 'Sent' folder for the account. The 'Sent' folder should be shown in the left Folder Pane below the name of your account folder.

I would need more info about your account set up to offer more specifics. eg: Is this a Pop account or an Imap account?

If Pop then Thunderbrd would create the 'Sent' folder when you sent the first email.

If Imap, then you should be subscribed to see the server folder for storing sent mail. That folder may be called: 'Sent Mail' or 'Sent Items' or 'Sent'

It also depends upon what you have set up as the location for storing sent mail.

  • Menu icon > Account Settings
  • Select 'Copies & Folders' for the account.

When sending messages automatically:

  • Select 'Place a copy in'

If POP account

  • Select 'Sent folder on' and choose the pop account email address.

If IMAP account

  • Select 'Other' and choose eg: 'Sent Mail on account email address' or whatever the server 'Sent' folder is called on that account
creator: Toad-Hall

content: If you put the email address in correctly the server would change.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I now would not like to accept the security exception permanently. I think this is best practice not to accept such a exception?

That would be a reasonable approach. However, it's ultimately up to you to decide whether you want to trust a cert or not. In this particular case the cert from the 3rd screenshot looks legitimate to me. It's been issued on Jan 3 2023, exactly the time the trouble started. Have you checked a support forum for t-online.de email, whether there were more complaints about this? I wouldn't be surprised if that was the case.

The problem seems to be the lack of a complete certificate chain, up to a trusted root certificate Thunderbird knows. This may well be a configuration problem at t-online.de. Have you checked with them yet?

Also in your 3rd screenshot, further down there's a link 'PEM (chain)'. Clicking the link should reveal a .pem file with the cert(s) for the entire certificate chain. You can try to import the .pem file into Thunderbird Certificate Manager underneath the 'Authorities' tab. See if that helps.
creator: christ1

content:
Dear christ1, thank you for your reply.

I have contacted t-online.de, but only via phone, there was no one who really understands my problem and they denied that it is t-online.de 's fault, and proposed it would rather be a Thunderbird issue... I will now set up a proper ticket to them...

Just for additional input: I have visited a Telekom subsidiary which I assume is responsible for all the certificate management: https://telesec.de/de/aktuelles/

There they say (translated): "New CPS version 19.0 online A new version was made available in Business.ID on January 10, 2023. From January 10th, 2023, the CPS Public will apply to all certificates below the public root CAs. the public certificates of Business.ID (SBCA). The CPS Business.ID continues to apply to the certificates from Business.ID below the internal root CAs. Your Business.ID (SBCA) team"

May this clarify anything? The date 10.Jan 2023 closely corresponds also with the time beginning of my issue.

Regarding your last paragraph. I see the link to 'PEM (chain)' but I do not know what to do with the data, FF offers me either to open the file or save to disk. What should / could I do at this point?

Same question with the Authority Info (AIA) ocspr file from http://ocsp.serverid.telesec.de/ocspr and http://crt.serverid.telesec.de/crt/Telekom_Security_ServerID_OV_Class_2_CA.crt What should / could I do at this point?

How do import the .pem file into Thunderbird Certificate Manager underneath the 'Authorities' tab. Where will i find the 'Authorities' tab?

kind regards
creator: nare73

content:
May this clarify anything?

I have no idea what they are talking about. But it seems on that website you can download any of the root and/or intermediate CA certs you may be missing.

I see the link to 'PEM (chain)' but I do not know what to do with the data

Download the .pem file and save it to your disk. Then import it into Thunderbird as described above using the Certificate Manager. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡ > Settings > Privacy & Security > Manage Certificates

Same question with the Authority Info (AIA) ocspr file

I'm not sure what this is for, but I don't think it's relevant for you.

and http://crt.serverid.telesec.de/crt/Telekom_Security_ServerID_OV_Class_2_CA.crt What should / could I do at this point?

That is the certificate for the CA which issued your new secureimap.t-online.de cert on 01/03/23. It's the intermediate CA certificate you need to import into Thunderbird.

In turn the intermediate CA certificate has been issued by the T-TeleSec GlobalRoot Class 2 root CA. That root cert is already present in Thunderbird's certificate store, assuming you're using a recent version of Thunderbird.
creator: christ1

content:
Dear christ1,

thank you very much for your replay and your answers! On of your hints got me to the solution of my issue, see below.

At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡ > Settings > Privacy & Security > Manage Certificates

and

In turn the intermediate CA certificate has been issued by the T-TeleSec GlobalRoot Class 2 root CA. That root cert is already present in Thunderbird's certificate store, assuming you're using a recent version of Thunderbird.

This was the your direct hint to find the reason of my issue. :-) I had a look into Thunderbird Certificate Manager underneath the 'Authorities' (Zertifizierunsgstellen, in German) tab the CA certificate T-TeleSec GlobalRoot Class 2 with 'Edit Trust' (Vertrauen bearbeiten, in German). There I found that the check box for 'this certificate can identify websights' was not checked. I switched that on, restarted Thunderbird - bingo - the issue was gone :) DONE.

Thank you very much for your help, with this I now do have a slightly better understanding of this CA stuff. Kind regards
creator: nare73

content:
Perhaps you have the same problem as https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1402654 who somehow has multiple copies of the account on disk?

With some care, I think you could just start from scratch with this account: 0. If you have any filters, write them down, and copy the msgfilters.dat file from the account directory to a safe location. 1. In Thunderbird account settings, delete the account and tell it to also delete the data 2. With Thunderbird shut down, recheck the OS for any files that got left under imap.gmail.com and delete them 3. also delete global-messages-db.sqlite 4. Start Thunderbird and add the imap account. 5. Immediately unsubscribe from "All Mail" folder, which for gmail is just an archive directory. You don't need it in Thunderbird. Right+click on the account and pick subscribe, then uncheck All Mail. Restart TB, shut it down, and delete the All Mail folders and files on disk. 6. copy msgfilters.dat back to the account directory 

Also suggest you
  • Try to delete some of your larger messages to reduce space
  • Set Thunderbird to do compact at some higher value, like 500 (MB)
creator: wsmwk

content:
Usually that sort of error comes down to something in the antivirus program in use. If both your settings are the same and you use the same modem/router to access the Optus service.

There have been issues with office365 where those with IPV6 enabled are having issues and that would be more likely on windows 11 than 10 I would guess. There is a network.dns.disableIPv6 pref which can be accessed via the config editor which will allow you to turn it off temporarily (or permanently) to see if that might be the issue.

BTW Hi from the Flinders, where I am looking for an alternative to the NBN.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
That bug has recently been reported: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1794241

I believe it works much better in 'Horizontal' view. In 'Address Book' On the right side of the search is an icon - click on it and at the bottom of list select 'Switch to Horizontal Layout'


I was able to reproduce the same effect. To reproduce issue:

  • View > Density > Compact
  • Then I increased the font size: View > Font Size > Increase font

I had to increase a couple of times, but I saw same overlapping effect in Address Book.

To fix I did either of the following:

  • Either: set - View > Density > Normal

This instantly fixed the overlapping font without needing to reduce the font size.

OR Keep using Density > 'Compact', but reduce the font size :

  • View > Font Size > 'Reduce font size' or 'Reset font size'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thanks very much for your kind help


I did as you said and went for HORIZONTAL

then I tried increasing font size,,, which it wouldn't allow me 

So then did ~ View~density~compact

So then,, just to experiment I went BACK to vertical layout,, and Lo and behold,,, it had fixed it,  and was now working and was readable !

You can  learn something everyday  !!

Sorry to take so long to to reply to your message suggestion,,  but I hadn't been that well for a week.

Advt wishes

John James

content: Perhaps provide some information about the server name you are connecting to. Many of the random disconnect issues are the result of wrong connection settings or the inclusion of IPV6 in the stack for TCPIP. Microsoft at least appears to have issues with that at office365.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
re :on opening up she met with what looked like an octopus in the middle of the page on the left-hand side of the page it asked for an email address, and password;


That sounds like Thunderbird started up and asked your wife to create a new mail account.

Thunderbird will do that if for some unknown reason it could not locate the original profile and has created a new profile which has no mail accounts OR Thunderbird is using the original profile but has lost the preferences which told it mail accounts already existed.

First check to see if there are other profile name folders and try to use them.

  • Menu icon > Help > More Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' section near the bottom locate 'Profiles' and click on 'about:profiles' - see image below as guide.

It will open in a new tab. It will list all the profiles - see image below as guide.

One of the profiles will say the name of the profile followed by 'This is the profile in use.....' It will say 'Default Profile: Yes' Make a note of which one is currently the default profile.

If you see additional profiles, they will have several buttons below. Test to see which of the additional profiles launches and looks good: Below the profile name - Click on 'Launch Profile' It will open in a new window Does that Thunderbird profile open correctly showing mail accounts ? If no, then close that Thunderbird window Back in the 'about:profiles' check another profile using the 'Launch Profile'

If it looks looks good: Close that new window. Back in the 'about:profiles' window locate that good profile this time click on 'Set as default profile' and then click on 'Launch Profile' It opens in a new window. This is now the Thunderbird you use. Close the original Thunderbird window.


What if there is only one profile listed, set as default and you are using it: Then you need to check to see if the preferences have a new 'prefs.js' file. In the 'about:profiles': That profile will have a 'Root directory' and on far right a 'Open Folder' button

  • Click on 'Open Folder' button - see image below

A new window opens showing the contents of that profile name folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now - this is important.
  • scroll down and locate the file called 'prefs.js'

Do you see more files of same name but they have an additional number eg: 'prefs-1.js ? If yes: locate the 'prefs-n.js' where 'n' is the largest number - does it have a good size which is greater than the current 'prefs.js' file?

If yes:

  • Rename 'prefs.js' as 'prefs.js.old'
  • Rename the 'prefs-n.js' (where n is highest number) as 'prefs.js'

How many 'prefs-n.js' files do you see? You can delete any that have a zero size. If all works ok then you can go back and delete the additional 'n' files later on.

Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall
